issue.title: Code & tests for OpenAPI 2.0 & 3.0 validation
issue.body:
Addresses issue #1892 by adding support for validating against OpenAPI 2.0 & 3.0 documents. Specifically:

1. Adds the concept of a Specification to schema.h. 
Specification may be a JSON schema draft or an OpenAPI version. 
Recognise all drafts but initially only supports Draft 04, Draft 05, Swagger 2.0 & OpenAPI 3.0.

2. When validating, obtains the schema specification.
Either from the schema if it contains it, or let the user specify it, or default to Draft 04.

3. Adjusts the validation rules according to the specification. 
Draft 04 & Draft 05 are identical in terms of validation rules.
Swagger 2.0 is based on Draft 04 with extensions and restrictions.
OpenAPI 3.0 is based on Draft 05 with extensions and restrictions. 

4. Adds additional error messages for violations of the new rules.

5. Adds unit tests to cover all new code.

In addition to the above, this PR:
a) Adds extra debug print methods
b) Replaces macro RAPIDJSON_INVALID_KEYWORD_VERBOSE with new macro RAPIDJSON_SCHEMA_PRINT
c) Uses RAPIDJSON_SCHEMA_PRINT throughout to make debugging easier
d) Removes `depth_` from the control of RAPIDJSON_SCHEMA_VERBOSE

comment.body: @smhdfdl I will try to review this this week

issue.title: Fix the address sanitizer problems
issue.body:
This PR is intended to address the SIMD unit test sanitizer problem identified in issue #2019, and any other sanitizer problems that are being thrown up when running other RapidJSON unit tests under `valgrind` .  #2019 contains the list but in summary:

1) SIMD.SkipWhitespace  
- Invalid read of size 16 (the original subject of issue #2019)
- Conditional jump or move depends on uninitialised value(s)
- Use of uninitialised value of size 8

2) Uri.Parse_UTF16 with std::string
- Invalid read of size 32

I am seeing all these on `master` branch (Fedora 36).

comment.body: I think `-NaN` should be invalid

pull_request.title: Add support of parsing INFINITY and NAN according to the standard.
pull_request.body: Variables of floating point types that have non-normal values, such as `INFINITY` and `NAN`, cannot be parsed by `GenericDocument::Parse(const Ch* str)` even if the flag `kParseNanAndInfFlag` is set, and that's due to the fact that the parser tests these exceptional values against `NaN`, `Infinity`, `-Infinity`, `Inf` and `-Inf`. However, according to the standard, when converting floating point types to string, e.g. using `std::to_string(double)`, these exceptional values get converted as `nan`, `inf` or `-inf`! This pull request fixes this issue (#2099).

repo.name: rapidjson
repo.description: A fast JSON parser/generator for C++ with both SAX/DOM style API

However, according to the standard, when converting floating point types to string, e.g. using `std::to_string(double)`, these exceptional values get converted as `nan`, `inf` or `-inf`! issue.title: Add schema error detection to GenericSchemaDocument
issue.body:
Fixes #1841 by adding detection of schema errors that would not be found by meta-schema validation. It works in a similar way to the validator errors, and creates a very similar error structure which you can access using `GenericSchemaDocument::GetError()`. 
The majority of errors relate to the processing of `$ref` keyword.
Also moves Pointer errors into the error framework.
Also improves the validation error for matching multiple `oneOf` items by including the indices of the first two matches.

comment.body: Thank @smhdfdl for your hard work and @ylavic for your help.

pull_request.title: Add schema error detection to GenericSchemaDocument
pull_request.body:
Fixes #1841 by adding detection of schema errors that would not be found by meta-schema validation. It works in a similar way to the validator errors, and creates a very similar error structure which you can access using `GenericSchemaDocument::GetError()`. 
The majority of errors relate to the processing of `$ref` keyword.
Also moves Pointer errors into the error framework.
Also improves the validation error for matching multiple `oneOf` items by including the indices of the first two matches.

repo.name: rapidjson
repo.description: A fast JSON parser/generator for C++ with both SAX/DOM style API

issue.title: GenericSchemaDocument does not report errors
issue.body: There is currently no concept in the GenericSchemaDocument of detecting errors in the JSON document it is 'compiling'.  It can't __return__ an error, because all the processing happens in the constructor. But it could set a private member and provide a getter method to return an error code.  The class is obviously written to be tolerant but I think some error reporting is needed. In our usage, we validate a JSON schema against the Draft-04 metaschema, before letting it be used to validate instance documents, but that doesn't catch things like failure to resolve a $ref.  @miloyip your thoughts please. I am happy to create a PR.

issue.title: The parser cannot parse non-normal values!
issue.body:
Hi, 
The parser `GenericDocument::Parse(const Ch* str)` fails to parse non-normal values such as `INFINITY`, `-INFINITY` and `NAN` for floating point data types. These exceptional values are supported officially by the standard, however the parser still can't parse them correctly!

This is actually very argent from our end, thus any soon feedback would be appreciated;-) thanks.

comment.body: Shall this be relaxed to case-insensitve?

Fixes #1841 by adding detection of schema errors that would not be found by meta-schema validation. It works in a similar way to the validator errors, and creates a very similar error structure which you can access using `GenericSchemaDocument::GetError()`. 
The majority of errors relate to the processing of `$ref` keyword.
Also moves Pointer errors into the error framework.
Also improves the validation error for matching multiple `oneOf` items by including the indices of the first two matches.

comment.body:
I found that the failed configurations in appveyor are those with `cmake  -DRAPIDJSON_USE_MEMBERSMAP=ON`.

I can reproduce the errors in docker (debian:latest on mac/arm64):

~~~
root@7a8b2f3b4755:/rapidjson/build# valgrind bin/unittest 
...
[ RUN      ] SchemaValidator.Schema_RefPlainNameRemote
==1497== Invalid read of size 8
==1497==    at 0x28BF50: Clear (allocators.h:280)
==1497==    by 0x28BF50: ~MemoryPoolAllocator (allocators.h:268)
==1497==    by 0x28BF50: rapidjson::MemoryPoolAllocator<rapidjson::CrtAllocator>::~MemoryPoolAllocator() (allocators.h:259)
==1497==    by 0x29BC2F: ~StdAllocator (allocators.h:506)
==1497==    by 0x29BC2F: ~_Rb_tree_impl (stl_tree.h:677)
==1497==    by 0x29BC2F: ~_Rb_tree (stl_tree.h:991)
==1497==    by 0x29BC2F: ~multimap (stl_multimap.h:297)
==1497==    by 0x29BC2F: DoFreeMembers (document.h:2254)
==1497==    by 0x29BC2F: rapidjson::GenericValue<rapidjson::UTF8<char>, rapidjson::MemoryPoolAllocator<rapidjson::CrtAllocator> >::~GenericValue() (document.h:898)
==1497==    by 0x29BC57: ~GenericMember (document.h:120)
==1497==    by 0x29BC57: DoFreeMembers (document.h:2256)
==1497==    by 0x29BC57: rapidjson::GenericValue<rapidjson::UTF8<char>, rapidjson::MemoryPoolAllocator<rapidjson::CrtAllocator> >::~GenericValue() (document.h:898)
==1497==    by 0x5C886F: rapidjson::GenericSchemaDocument<rapidjson::GenericValue<rapidjson::UTF8<char>, rapidjson::MemoryPoolAllocator<rapidjson::CrtAllocator> >, rapidjson::MemoryPoolAllocator<rapidjson::CrtAllocator> >::~GenericSchemaDocument() (schema.h:1739)
==1497==    by 0x5AAE53: SchemaValidator_Schema_RefPlainNameRemote_Test::TestBody() (schematest.cpp:3016)
==1497==    by 0x6E6A27: HandleSehExceptionsInMethodIfSupported<testing::Test, void> (gtest.cc:2418)
==1497==    by 0x6E6A27: void testing::internal::HandleExceptionsInMethodIfSupported<testing::Test, void>(testing::Test*, void (testing::Test::*)(), char const*) (gtest.cc:2454)
==1497==    by 0x6DC887: testing::Test::Run() [clone .part.0] (gtest.cc:2492)
==1497==    by 0x6DCB0F: Run (gtest.cc:2484)

==1497==    by 0x6DCC73: Run (gtest.cc:2643)
==1497==    by 0x6DCC73: testing::TestCase::Run() [clone .part.0] (gtest.cc:2786)
==1497==    by 0x6DD373: Run (gtest.cc:2772)
==1497==    by 0x6DD373: testing::internal::UnitTestImpl::RunAllTests() (gtest.cc:5048)
==1497==    by 0x6DD57B: HandleSehExceptionsInMethodIfSupported<testing::internal::UnitTestImpl, bool> (gtest.cc:2418)
==1497==    by 0x6DD57B: HandleExceptionsInMethodIfSupported<testing::internal::UnitTestImpl, bool> (gtest.cc:2454)
==1497==    by 0x6DD57B: testing::UnitTest::Run() (gtest.cc:4664)
==1497==    by 0x2842AF: RUN_ALL_TESTS (gtest.h:2329)
==1497==    by 0x2842AF: main (unittest.cpp:44)
...
~~~

So I think there is a real problem when using that option.

issue.title: Problem verifing schema with multipleOf == 0.1

comment.body:
@smhdfdl What "robust" solution do you have in mind?
I think there may be several solutions:
1. absolute or relative threshold
2. decimal representation
3. rational representation
For any one of these, user may need to configure some settings in order to make it work.

issue.title: json object key lost  amazing

comment.body:
`cp` is local variable in `afun()`. So when the function is returned the data allocated in `cp` is invalid.
Using `cp.CopyFrom(d, dd.GetAllocator()` instead should fix this.
BTW, you can simply use `Value cp(d, dd.GetAllocator());`, or even `dd.AddMember("data", Value(d, dd.GetAllocator()).Move());`.

comment.body:
`cp` is local variable in `afun()`. So when the function is returned the data allocated in `cp` is invalid.
Using `cp.CopyFrom(d, dd.GetAllocator()` instead should fix this.
BTW, you can simply use `Value cp(d, dd.GetAllocator());`, or even `dd.AddMember("data", Value(d, dd.GetAllocator()).Move());`.

issue.title: Code & tests for OpenAPI 2.0 & 3.0 validation
issue.body:
Addresses issue #1892 by adding support for validating against OpenAPI 2.0 & 3.0 documents. Specifically:

1. Adds the concept of a Specification to schema.h. 
Specification may be a JSON schema draft or an OpenAPI version. 
Recognise all drafts but initially only supports Draft 04, Draft 05, Swagger 2.0 & OpenAPI 3.0.

2. When validating, obtains the schema specification.
Either from the schema if it contains it, or let the user specify it, or default to Draft 04.

3. Adjusts the validation rules according to the specification. 
Draft 04 & Draft 05 are identical in terms of validation rules.
Swagger 2.0 is based on Draft 04 with extensions and restrictions.
OpenAPI 3.0 is based on Draft 05 with extensions and restrictions. 

4. Adds additional error messages for violations of the new rules.

5. Adds unit tests to cover all new code.

In addition to the above, this PR:
a) Adds extra debug print methods
b) Replaces macro RAPIDJSON_INVALID_KEYWORD_VERBOSE with new macro RAPIDJSON_SCHEMA_PRINT
c) Uses RAPIDJSON_SCHEMA_PRINT throughout to make debugging easier
d) Removes `depth_` from the control of RAPIDJSON_SCHEMA_VERBOSE

comment.body: @smhdfdl I will try to review this this week

issue.title: Fix the address sanitizer problems
issue.body:
This PR is intended to address the SIMD unit test sanitizer problem identified in issue #2019, and any other sanitizer problems that are being thrown up when running other RapidJSON unit tests under `valgrind` .  #2019 contains the list but in summary:

1) SIMD.SkipWhitespace  
- Invalid read of size 16 (the original subject of issue #2019)
- Conditional jump or move depends on uninitialised value(s)
- Use of uninitialised value of size 8

2) Uri.Parse_UTF16 with std::string
- Invalid read of size 32

I am seeing all these on `master` branch (Fedora 36).

comment.body: I think `-NaN` should be invalid

pull_request.title: Add support of parsing INFINITY and NAN according to the standard.
pull_request.body: Variables of floating point types that have non-normal values, such as `INFINITY` and `NAN`, cannot be parsed by `GenericDocument::Parse(const Ch* str)` even if the flag `kParseNanAndInfFlag` is set, and that's due to the fact that the parser tests these exceptional values against `NaN`, `Infinity`, `-Infinity`, `Inf` and `-Inf`. However, according to the standard, when converting floating point types to string, e.g. using `std::to_string(double)`, these exceptional values get converted as `nan`, `inf` or `-inf`! This pull request fixes this issue (#2099).

issue.title: Add schema error detection to GenericSchemaDocument
issue.body:
Fixes #1841 by adding detection of schema errors that would not be found by meta-schema validation. It works in a similar way to the validator errors, and creates a very similar error structure which you can access using `GenericSchemaDocument::GetError()`. 
The majority of errors relate to the processing of `$ref` keyword.
Also moves Pointer errors into the error framework.
Also improves the validation error for matching multiple `oneOf` items by including the indices of the first two matches.

comment.body: Thank @smhdfdl for your hard work and @ylavic for your help.

pull_request.title: Add schema error detection to GenericSchemaDocument
pull_request.body:
Fixes #1841 by adding detection of schema errors that would not be found by meta-schema validation. It works in a similar way to the validator errors, and creates a very similar error structure which you can access using `GenericSchemaDocument::GetError()`. 
The majority of errors relate to the processing of `$ref` keyword.
Also moves Pointer errors into the error framework.
Also improves the validation error for matching multiple `oneOf` items by including the indices of the first two matches.

issue.title: GenericSchemaDocument does not report errors
issue.body: There is currently no concept in the GenericSchemaDocument of detecting errors in the JSON document it is 'compiling'.  It can't __return__ an error, because all the processing happens in the constructor. But it could set a private member and provide a getter method to return an error code.  The class is obviously written to be tolerant but I think some error reporting is needed. In our usage, we validate a JSON schema against the Draft-04 metaschema, before letting it be used to validate instance documents, but that doesn't catch things like failure to resolve a $ref.  @miloyip your thoughts please. I am happy to create a PR.

issue.title: The parser cannot parse non-normal values!
issue.body:
Hi, 
The parser `GenericDocument::Parse(const Ch* str)` fails to parse non-normal values such as `INFINITY`, `-INFINITY` and `NAN` for floating point data types. These exceptional values are supported officially by the standard, however the parser still can't parse them correctly!

This is actually very argent from our end, thus any soon feedback would be appreciated;-) thanks.

comment.body: Shall this be relaxed to case-insensitve?

Fixes #1841 by adding detection of schema errors that would not be found by meta-schema validation. It works in a similar way to the validator errors, and creates a very similar error structure which you can access using `GenericSchemaDocument::GetError()`. 
The majority of errors relate to the processing of `$ref` keyword.

Also improves the validation error for matching multiple `oneOf` items by including the indices of the first two matches.

comment.body:
I found that the failed configurations in appveyor are those with `cmake  -DRAPIDJSON_USE_MEMBERSMAP=ON`.

I can reproduce the errors in docker (debian:latest on mac/arm64):

~~~
root@7a8b2f3b4755:/rapidjson/build# valgrind bin/unittest 
...
[ RUN      ] SchemaValidator.Schema_RefPlainNameRemote
==1497== Invalid read of size 8
==1497==    at 0x28BF50: Clear (allocators.h:280)
==1497==    by 0x28BF50: ~MemoryPoolAllocator (allocators.h:268)
==1497==    by 0x28BF50: rapidjson::MemoryPoolAllocator<rapidjson::CrtAllocator>::~MemoryPoolAllocator() (allocators.h:259)
==1497==    by 0x29BC2F: ~StdAllocator (allocators.h:506)
==1497==    by 0x29BC2F: ~_Rb_tree_impl (stl_tree.h:677)
==1497==    by 0x29BC2F: ~_Rb_tree (stl_tree.h:991)
==1497==    by 0x29BC2F: ~multimap (stl_multimap.h:297)
==1497==    by 0x29BC2F: DoFreeMembers (document.h:2254)
==1497==    by 0x29BC2F: rapidjson::GenericValue<rapidjson::UTF8<char>, rapidjson::MemoryPoolAllocator<rapidjson::CrtAllocator> >::~GenericValue() (document.h:898)
==1497==    by 0x29BC57: ~GenericMember (document.h:120)
==1497==    by 0x29BC57: DoFreeMembers (document.h:2256)
==1497==    by 0x29BC57: rapidjson::GenericValue<rapidjson::UTF8<char>, rapidjson::MemoryPoolAllocator<rapidjson::CrtAllocator> >::~GenericValue() (document.h:898)
==1497==    by 0x5C886F: rapidjson::GenericSchemaDocument<rapidjson::GenericValue<rapidjson::UTF8<char>, rapidjson::MemoryPoolAllocator<rapidjson::CrtAllocator> >, rapidjson::MemoryPoolAllocator<rapidjson::CrtAllocator> >::~GenericSchemaDocument() (schema.h:1739)
==1497==    by 0x5AAE53: SchemaValidator_Schema_RefPlainNameRemote_Test::TestBody() (schematest.cpp:3016)
==1497==    by 0x6E6A27: HandleSehExceptionsInMethodIfSupported<testing::Test, void> (gtest.cc:2418)
==1497==    by 0x6E6A27: void testing::internal::HandleExceptionsInMethodIfSupported<testing::Test, void>(testing::Test*, void (testing::Test::*)(), char const*) (gtest.cc:2454)
==1497==    by 0x6DC887: testing::Test::Run() [clone .part.0] (gtest.cc:2492)
==1497==    by 0x6DCB0F: Run (gtest.cc:2484)
==1497==    by 0x6DCB0F: testing::TestInfo::Run() [clone .part.0] (gtest.cc:2668)
==1497==    by 0x6DCC73: Run (gtest.cc:2643)
==1497==    by 0x6DCC73: testing::TestCase::Run() [clone .part.0] (gtest.cc:2786)
==1497==    by 0x6DD373: Run (gtest.cc:2772)
==1497==    by 0x6DD373: testing::internal::UnitTestImpl::RunAllTests() (gtest.cc:5048)
==1497==    by 0x6DD57B: HandleSehExceptionsInMethodIfSupported<testing::internal::UnitTestImpl, bool> (gtest.cc:2418)
==1497==    by 0x6DD57B: HandleExceptionsInMethodIfSupported<testing::internal::UnitTestImpl, bool> (gtest.cc:2454)
==1497==    by 0x6DD57B: testing::UnitTest::Run() (gtest.cc:4664)
==1497==    by 0x2842AF: RUN_ALL_TESTS (gtest.h:2329)
==1497==    by 0x2842AF: main (unittest.cpp:44)
...

So I think there is a real problem when using that option.

issue.title: Problem verifing schema with multipleOf == 0.1

comment.body:
@smhdfdl What "robust" solution do you have in mind?
I think there may be several solutions:
1. absolute or relative threshold
2. decimal representation
3. rational representation
For any one of these, user may need to configure some settings in order to make it work.
